Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Story: I glanced at my phone, the group chat with my siblings lighting up with messages: “Don’t be late for the family dinner!” and “We’re counting on you to help with the decorations.” It was our annual holiday celebration, and everyone expected me to be there, laughing and sharing stories, just like every year. But as I pulled up to the curb, a passenger slid into the back seat, breathless and anxious. “Please, I need to get to the train station—my train leaves in thirty minutes. Can you make it?” I nodded, feeling the weight of his urgency. My job was to get him there safely and on time, no matter the traffic or the clock ticking down. But my family was waiting, expecting me to show up, to be present, to be a good sibling. My hands tightened on the steering wheel as I stared at the red light ahead, torn between the pull of family and the responsibility of my job, both demanding more than I could give at once.
